name: Zarankiewicz problem
rephrased: What is the maximum number of edges in a bipartite graph without a complete bipartite subgraph of size s by t?
implication_form: If a bipartite graph has more than Z(m,n;s,t) edges, then it must contain a complete bipartite subgraph K_{s,t} (where Z(m,n;s,t) is the Zarankiewicz function representing the maximum edges without K_{s,t}).
explained: The Zarankiewicz problem is an unsolved problem in extremal graph theory. It asks for the maximum number of edges in a bipartite graph with parts of size m and n, respectively, that does not contain a complete bipartite subgraph of the form K_{s,t} (where s and t are given positive integers). The maximum is denoted as z(m,n;s,t). A special case is when the forbidden subgraph is a complete bipartite subgraph with one part of size s and the other part of size t.
terms: Zarankiewicz function, Zarankiewicz number, bipartite graph, extremal graph theory, complete bipartite subgraph K_{s,t}, Turán number, bipartite Turán number
related_conjectures: Bipartite Turán number conjecture (which is a generalization), Zarankiewicz problem for specific parameters (e.g., the conjectured value of z(n,n;2,2) relates to the bipartite Kneser graph problem)
subjects: Extremal graph theory, combinatorics, extremal set theory, Ramsey theory
